concept.title: Writing tasks
concept.shortdesc: tasks are similar to scripts, but they are kept in modules and can have metadata. This allows you to reuse and share them.

conbody.p: You can write tasks in any programming language the target nodes run, such as Bash, , or Python. A task can even be a compiled binary that runs on the target. Place your task in the ./tasks directory of a module and add a metadata file to describe parameters and configure task behavior.
For a task to run on remote systems, it must include a shebang (#!) line at the top of the file to specify the interpreter.
For example, the mysql::sql task is written in and provides the path to the interpreter. This example also accepts several parameters as JSON on stdin and returns an error.

p.codeblock:
#!/opt/puppetlabs/puppet/bin/ruby require 'json' require 'open3' require 'puppet'
def get(sql, database, user, password) cmd = ['mysql', '-e', "#{sql} "] cmd << "--database=#{database}" unless database.nil? cmd << "--user=#{user}" unless user.nil? cmd << "--password=#{password}" unless password.nil? stdout, stderr, status = Open3.capture3(*cmd) # rubocop:disable Lint/UselessAssignment raise Puppet::Error, _("stderr: ' %{stderr}') % { stderr: stderr }") if status != 0 { status: stdout.strip } end
params = JSON.parse(STDIN.read) database = params['database'] user = params['user'] password = params['password'] sql = params['sql']
begin result = get(sql, database, user, password) puts result.to_json exit 0 rescue Puppet::Error => e puts({ status: 'failure', error: e.message }.to_json) exit 1 end
